metadata.title: Asphalt modification using nano-materials and polymers composite considering high and low temperature performance

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Construction and Building Materials
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate /conbui ldmat
Asphalt modification using nano-materials and polymers composite considering high and low temperature performance
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.conbuildmat.2016.12.073 0950-0618/ 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
⇑ Corresponding author at: Department of Civil Engineering, The Catholic University of America, Washington, DC 20064, USA.
E-mail addresses: sunl@cua.edu (L. Sun), xinxiantao1986@126.com (X. Xin), worjl@126.com (J. Ren).
Lu Sun a,b,⇑, Xiantao Xin c, Jiaolong Ren a a School of Transportation, Southeast University, Nanjing 210096, China bDepartment of Civil Engineering, The Catholic University of America, Washington, DC 20064, USA cChinese Ministry of Transport, Port Design Corporation, Shanghai, China
h i g h l i g h t s
Nano-materials and polymers are proposed as composite modifiers of asphalt. Enhanced asphalt performances at high-temperature and low-temperature are achieved. Screening of nano-materials and polymers is based on asphalt performance indicators. Orthogonal experiment design determines optimal composite modifiers.
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 30 January 2016 Received in revised form 11 October 2016 Accepted 16 December 2016
Keywords: Nano-materials Polymers Composite modified asphalt binder Orthogonal experiment design Pavement performance
a b s t r a c t
Nano-materials have a great potent ial as modifiers for enhancing performance of base asphalt binder. However, existing studies in the literature focus on the improvement of high-temperature performance of base asphalt binder, whereas the low-temperature performance of base asphalt binder is overlooked. Studies have shown that nano-materials will even weaken the low-temperature performance of base asphalt binder. To address this issue, nano-materials and polymers as composite modifiers are studied to improve base asphalt performance at both high temperature and low temperature. Nano-materials and polymers were screened and selected according to conventional performance indicator of asphalt binder, including softening point, ductility at 5 C and viscosity at 60 C. Optimal formulas of composite modifiers were determined using orthogonal experiment design and range analysis. SHRP tests including RTFOT, DSR and BBR tests were conducted to better evaluate the anti-aging, high-temperature performance and low temperature performance (i.e., crack resistance and water stability) of the proposed optimal composite modified asphalt binder against performances of 5%SBS modified asphalt binder and AH-70 base asphalt binder, showing an improved pavement performance.
2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
As construction materials for highway and airport, asphalt is used as a binder to form asphalt mixture. To improve the pavement performance of asphalt mixture, different types of materials including resins, rubbers, polymers, sulfur, metal complexes, fibres and chemical agents have been used to overcome the hightemperature performance, low-temperature crack resistance and aging resistance of base asphalt binder.
Because of morphological features on the nano-scale dimensions, nano-materials have some special properties, such as large specific surface area, high surface free energy and good ability for dispersion [12]. Nano-materials are of great scientific interest as they represent an effective bridge between bulk materials and atomic/molecular structures [2]. Mechanical, thermodynamic, electrical, magnetic, optical and chemical properties of nanomaterials are subject to considerable changes when the material is examined at different scales: from a macro scale to a nano scale.
Performance of asphalt binder can be improved through physical and chemical action between nano-materials and asphalt materials. In recent years, nanotechnology has gradually been incorporated into the field of modified asphalt with various kinds of nano-materials being used to modify asphalt. Polacco et al. [10,11] and Zare-Shahabadi et al. [22] analyzed the effect of
bentonite clay and synthesized organic bentonite on the rheological properties of the modified asphalt. Jahromi et al. [4] discussed the influence of nano-layered silicate on the rheological properties of modified asphalt. Goh et al. [3] analyzed the mechanical properties and water resistance of nano-clay and carbon-fibre modified asphalt binder and asphalt mixture. Sureshkumar et al. [19] analyzed the road performance of EVA/nano-layered composite asphalt binder. Khattak et al. [7] characterized the high temperature performance of carbon nano-fibre modified hot mix asphalt mixture. Yusoff et al. [21] revealed the effect of moisture susceptibility and aging conditions on nano-silica/polymer modified asphalt mixture. Karahancer et al. [5] evaluated the pavement performance of nano-modified asphalt mixture. Yao et al. [20] analyzed the moisture susceptibility of nano hydrated lime modified asphalt mixture. Shafabakhsh et al. [14,13] investigated the rutting and fatigue performance of nano-TiO2/SiO2 modified asphalt mixture. Moreover, nano-CaCO3 particles [6], nano-ZnO particles [15,16] and nano-CaCO3 compound [17,18] have also been investigated to modify performance of asphalt with various levels of success. These studies show that nano-materials can significantly improve the road performance of base asphalt, especially the high-temperature performance, which proves the advantage and the feasibility of the application of nano-materials in modified asphalt.
However, most of existing studies only focus on the improvement of high-temperature performance, moisture susceptibility and aging resistance of base asphalt using nano-materials, whereas the low-temperature performance of nano-materials modified asphalt is overlooked. Even some studies have shown that nanomaterials weaken the low-temperature performance of base asphalt [15,16], which will lead an adverse effect to asphalt pavement in cold regions. To address this issue, nano-materials and polymers as composite modifiers are studied in this study to improve the overall performance of nano-modified asphalt at both high and low temperature.
The remainder of the paper is as follows. Nano-materials and polymers modifiers are selected in Section 2. The optimal formula of nano-materials and polymer composite modified asphalt is determined through orthogonal tests in Section 3. Physical properties of the proposed modified asphalt binder are tested in Section 4. Road performance of asphalt mixture using the proposed modified asphalt binder is analyzed in Section 5. The economic analysis and the engineering application are plotted in Sections 6 and 7, respectively. Conclusions are drawn in Section 8. Fig. 1 provides a graphical abstract of the procedures used in this study.

sections.heading: 2.1. Preparation procedure
sections.text: Due to the large specific surface area and the high surface energy, nano-materials have a great inclination to agglomerate to form secondary particles. When nano-materials are poorly dispersed in base asphalt binder, the modified effent of the nanocomposites will be similar to that of the micrometer-sized composites. Hence, it is necessary to disperse nano-materials uniformly to overcome the agglomeration problem. The preparation of nanomaterials and polymers modified asphalt binder is as follows. Firstly, nanomaterials were added into 500 g of base asphalt binder. After 5 min manual mixing and 15 min high-speed shearing (5000 r/min) at 120 C, polymers are mixed. Through 5000 r/min of high-speed shearing at 170 C for no fewer than 30 min, test specimens of composite nano-materials and polymer modified asphalt binder are prepared.

sections.heading: 2.2. Screening of nano-materials and polymers
sections.text:
The effectiveness of nano-materials and polymers as asphalt modifier depends on chemical composition and physical properties of the composite. It is necessary to screen out specific type of nanomaterials and polymers that exhibits superb engineering performance when modifying asphalt binder. Therefore, six types of nano-materials and four types of polymers are firstly used to modify base asphalt binder, among which the most suitable ones were selected according to a series of conventional tests for asphalt binder. The particle size and specific surface area of the selected nanomaterials are shown in Table 1. The technical parameters of the selected polymers are shown in Table 2.
Traditional performance indices for evaluating asphalt binders are penetration at 25 C, softening point, ductility at 5 C and Brookfield viscosity at 60 C. The softening point and Brookfield viscosity at 60 C denote the high temperature performance of asphalt binder, whereas the penetration at 25 C indicates the hardness of asphalt binder. Ductility at 5 C is related to low temperature performance of asphalt binder. All these tests were conducted following Chinese Technical Specification ‘‘Standard Test Methods of Bitumen and Bituminous Mixtures for Highway Engineering (JTJ 052-2000)”. Test results are shown in Table 3.
This study focuses on the modified asphalt binder with improved both high and low temperature performance. As shown in Table 3, SBR modified asphalt binder has the highest ductility,
rocedures used in this study.
especially when its dosage exceeds 4%, showing that polymer SBR can exhibits the low temperature performance of asphalt binder significantly. Hence, SBR is selected due to its superb lowtemperature property in modifying asphalt performance. Unfortunately, the high-temperature modified effect of SBR is not satisfying. Other modifiers should be selected to improve the hightemperature performance of asphalt binder. It can be found that SBS and PE bring an obvious increased effect on hightemperature performance to modified asphalt binder. However, SBS takes effect until its dosage exceeds 4%. Hence, PE is selected due to its superb high-temperature property and the economy.
Moreover, according to the previous studies [19,17,18,5], nanomaterials can amplify the improved effect on high temperature performance of modified asphalt binder, and it can be evaluated through the high-temperature performance of nanomaterial mod-
ified asphalt binder. As shown in Table 3, it can be found that the softening point and viscosity of nano-SiO2 and bentonite modified asphalt binder increased more obviously, illustrating that nanoSiO2 and bentonite can improve the high temperature performance better. Hence, nano-SiO2 and bentonite are selected to enhance the high temperature performance of modified asphalt binder further.
Therefore, SiO2, bentonite, SBR and PE are ultimately selected for further study due to their superb property in modifying asphalt performance at high temperature and low temperature.

sections.heading: 3.1. Orthogonal experiment
sections.text: In order to determine the optimal formula and cut the experimental number scientifically, orthogonal experiment method [9,8] is carried out in this study. Test factors and the corresponding test levels are shown in Table 4. The test level of nano-materials is selected according to the previous studies [15,16,17,18] and the test level of polymers is selected through Table 3. The design of orthogonal experiment is plotted in Table 5.

sections.heading: 3.2. Test results and analysis
sections.text: Softening point, ductility at 5 C and dynamic viscosity at 135 C are adopted to evaluate the high-temperature performance, low-

In the orthogonal analysis method, there are two key indexes including the average value of test results for each test level and the corresponding range for each test factor [9,8], as shown in Table 7. The range, as shown in Fig. 2, is used to evaluate the effect degree of different factors on the results, which is equal to the dif-

ference of the average value of different test levels for the same test factor. The average value is used to plot the tendency charts of each factor on the test results, as shown in Figs. 3–5.
The orthogonal analysis can follow the process below [9,8]. (1) The important performance indexes are determined. (2) The key test factor for the important performance index can be selected according to the value of range. (3) The best test level of the selected test factor can be determined according to the change tends of the selected test factor. (4) The best formula can be determined according to the key test factor and the best test level. (5) The selected formula can be adjusted according to the analysis of secondary performance indexes following step (2) and (3).
In this study, the important performance indexes are 5 C ductility (low temperature performance) and softening point (high temperature performance). The secondary performance index is 135 C ductility (workable performance).
As shown in Table 1 and Fig. 2(a), the range of SBR for 5 C ductility is the highest, showing that SBR has the most significant effect on the low-temperature performance of modified asphalt binder. According to Fig. 3, the effect trend of SBR grows rapidly when SBR dosage exceeds 4% and reaches a higher degree when

SBR dosage exceeds 5%. Hence, the dosage of SBR can be determined as 5% combining with the economy. On the other hand, as shown in Figs. 2(b) and 4, the modified effect of SiO2 and PE on the softening point is the most obvious. The effect trend of SiO2 slows down when the dosage exceeds 0.5% and the change of growth trend of PE is not obvious. Hence, the dosage of SiO2 and PE can be determined as 0.5% and 1%, respectively, combining with the economy.
Moreover, 135 C dynamic viscosity of modified asphalt binder should be controlled because of the workable performance. As shown in Figs. 2(c) and 5, bentonite brings a large increase of 135 C dynamic viscosity. Then, bentonite doesn’t employ in this study although bentonite can improve the high-temperature performance of asphalt binder. In addition, it can found that the impacts of SiO2 and PE on 135 C dynamic viscosity are relatively low when the dosage are 0.5% and 1%, respectively, showing that the choice of SiO2 and PE dosage is satisfying.
Thus, the formula of nano-materials and polymers composite modified asphalt binder can be recommended as 0.5%SiO2 + 5% SBR + 1%PE.

sections.heading: 4. Performance of modified asphalt binder
sections.text: The selected formula is further examined for its effectiveness in modifying asphalt performance including RTFOT, DSR and BBR tests. For the purposed of comparison, base asphalt AH-70 and 5%SBS modified asphalt binder were also tested.

sections.heading: 4.1. RTFOT for evaluating anti-aging performance
sections.text:
Mass loss, 25 C residual penetration ratio and 5 C ductility after aging through the RTFOT test are used to evaluate the antiaging performance of asphalt binders. The tests were conducted according to the standard method of AASHTO T240. The results are shown in Table 8.
As shown in Table 8, mass loss/residual penetration ratio of the proposed modified asphalt binder is lower/higher than that of AH70 base asphalt binder and 5%SBS modified asphalt binder. Particularly, 5 C ductility after aging of the proposed modified asphalt binder is 2.66 times higher than that of 5%SBS modified asphalt binder. It can be indicated that the proposed modified asphalt binder have a better anti-aging performance than base asphalt binder and 5%SBS modified asphalt binder.

sections.heading: 4.2. DSR test for evaluating high-temperature performance
sections.text:
The dynamic shear rheometer (DSR) tests are used to evaluate the high-temperature performance of asphalt binder. The Superpave specification defines and places requirements on a rutting factor, G⁄/sind, which represents a measure of the high temperature stiffness or rutting resistance of asphalt binder. With the development of research work and the application of various new binder materials, especially when the polymer modified asphalt binders are used, G⁄/sind is suggested to be ineffective in capturing the contribution to rutting resistance [1]. This factor is determined by dividing the complex shear modulus (G⁄) by the sine of the phase angel (d), which is both measured using the DSR.
Auto-rheometer of type CVO100 made by Bohlin Instrument was used to conduct DSR tests in this research. The Superpave binder specification requires all the DSR tests to be performed at a frequency of 10 rad per second, which is approximately equal to 1.59 Hz. The tests were conducted according to the standard method of AASHTO T315. Rutting factor was selected for the performance index, and the test results (G⁄/sind) are shown in Table 9.
Compared with the base asphalt binder, whose G⁄/sind is greater than 1.0 KPa at 70 C, G⁄/sind of the proposed modified asphalt binder is still greater than 1.0 KPa at 88 C, jumping three temperature levels from 70 C to 88 C. Meanwhile, compared with the 5%SBS modified asphalt binder, G⁄/sind of the proposed modified asphalt binder is always higher than that of 5%SBS modified asphalt binder at the same temperature. These observations show that the proposed modified asphalt binder enhances the hightemperature performance of base asphalt binder and is superior to 5%SBS modified asphalt binder.

sections.heading: 4.3. BBR test for evaluating low-temperature performance
sections.text:
Low-temperature performance of asphalt binder is determined through Bending Beam Rheometer (BBR) and Direct Tension (DT) tests. BBR test applies a small creep load to a binder beam specimen and measures the creep stiffness (S) and creep rate (mvalue). The smaller values of S and the greater values of m show that asphalt binder is hard to accumulate the stress and crack at low-temperature. If the creep stiffness is between 300 MPa and 600 MPa and the m-value is greater than 0.3, DT test is required to be carried out by the specification. TE-BBR equipment made by Cannon Instrument was used to conduct BBR tests at 12 C in this study. These tests were conducted according to the standard method of AASHTO T313. The creep stiffness S and creep rate mvalues at 60 s of loading time are shown in Table 10.
As shown in Table 10, the S value of the proposed modified asphalt binder, on average across all tested temperatures, reduced 19.3% and 28.2%, when compared to 5%SBS modified asphalt binder and AH-70# base asphalt binder, respectively. The m value of the proposed modified asphalt binder, on average across all tested temperatures, increased 14.0% and 23.9%, when compared to 5% SBS modified asphalt binder and AH-70# base asphalt binder, respectively. These observations show that the proposed modified asphalt binder enhances the low-temperature performance of base asphalt binder and is superior than 5%SBS modified asphalt binder.

sections.heading: 5. Performance of modified asphalt mixture
sections.text: In order to further examine the effectiveness of the proposed modified asphalt in terms of improving performance of asphalt mixture, three kinds of asphalt mixture respectively using 5%SBS modified asphalt, the proposed modified asphalt and AH-70# base asphalt are prepared using aggregate gradation shown in Table 11. The aggregate gradation is obtained from that used in the surface course of the 1st section of ‘‘Dong-Yu” highway in Shanxi province of China. The asphalt-aggregate ratio of the three kinds of asphalt mixtures determined by Marshall test method is 5.0% (SBS asphalt mixture), 5.0% (the proposed asphalt mixture) and 4.7% (AH-70 asphalt mixture), respectively. The porosity of the three kinds of asphalt mixtures are 4.0% (SBS asphalt mixture), 3.8% (the proposed asphalt mixture) and 3.9% (AH-70 asphalt mixture), respectively. The density of the three kinds of asphalt mixtures are 2.409 g/cm3 (SBS asphalt mixture), 2.416 g/cm3 (the proposed asphalt mixture) and 2.411 g/cm3 (AH-70 asphalt mixture), respectively. The rutting tests, bending tests at low temperature ( 10 C) and immersion marshall tests/ freeze-thaw split tests are used to evaluate the high-temperature stability, low-temperature crack resistance and water stability of different kinds of asphalt mixture, respectively.

sections.heading: 5.1. High-temperature performance
sections.text:
Rutting test results of different types of asphalt mixture are shown in Table 12.
As previously mentioned (Table 9), the proposed modified asphalt binder has the best high-temperature performance. The same role also reflects in asphalt mixtures. As shown in Table 12,
Table 17 Analysis of price and performance of the proposed modified asphalt.

dynamic stability of the proposed modified asphalt mixture is the highest among all tested modifiers, which is 1.35 and 4.32 times higher than that of SBS modified asphalt mixture and AH-70 asphalt mixture, respectively. It indicates that the proposed modified asphalt mixture have better high-temperature stability.

sections.heading: 5.2. Low-temperature performance
sections.text:
Through the low-temperature bending test at 10 C, the lowtemperature performance of different kinds of asphalt mixture is tested. Test results are shown in Table 13.
As shown in Table 13, the proposed modified asphalt mixture has a larger failure strain and smaller stiffness modulus than other asphalt mixtures, indicating that it has a better low-temperature crack resistance. Among all tested modifiers, the failure strain of the proposed modified asphalt mixture is 1.60 and 2.55 times higher than that of SBS modified asphalt mixture and AH-70 asphalt mixture. The stiffness modulus of the proposed modified asphalt mixture reduces 20.2% and 33.2% compared to that of SBS modified asphalt mixture and AH-70 asphalt mixture.

sections.heading: 5.3. Water stability
sections.text:
The water stability of different kinds of asphalt mixture were evaluated through the immersing Marshall test and the freezethaw splitting test, as shown in Tables 14 and 15.
As shown in Tables 14 and 15, the residual stability and cleavage strength of two types of modified asphalts are similar to each other but higher than that of AH-70 asphalt mixture, indicating the effectiveness of modification in terms of water stability.

sections.heading: 6. Economic analysis
sections.text:
In this section, the relationship of economy and pavement performance of the proposed modified asphalt is analyzed through comparing to 5%SBS modified asphalt binder. Table 16 plots the unit price of different raw materials used in different modified asphalt binder. The price increase ratio (PR) and performance increase ratio (CR) of the proposed modified asphalt binders are shown in Table 17, which can be calculated through Eq. (1).
PR ¼ Pm=PSBS CR ¼ Cm=CSBS ð1Þ where Pm and Cm are the price and performance of the proposed modified asphalt binder, PSBS and CSBS are the price and performance of 5%SBS modified asphalt binder.
As shown in Table 15, the pavement performance of the proposed modified asphalt has a significant improvement composed to the 5%SBS modified asphalt, while the price of the proposed modified asphalt does not rise obviously. It indicates that the proposed modified asphalt brings an improved comprehensive performance.

sections.heading: 7. Engineering application
sections.text:
The proposed modified asphalt has been used in the surface course of the 1st section of ‘‘Dong-Yu” highway in Shanxi province of China. The length of the test road is 1.5 km, and 5%SBS modified asphalt is used in other segments of this highway. Fig. 6 shows the asphalt mixture using the proposed modified asphalt. It can be found that the asphalt mixture is mixed uniformly with luminous color. There is no segregation phenomenon.
Table 18 shows the performance comparison of asphalt mixture cores using the proposed modified asphalt and 5%SBS modified asphalt. It can be found that the stability of asphalt mixture core using the proposed modified asphalt is 1.28 times than that using 5%SBS modified asphalt, showing that the proposed modified asphalt binder provides an improved engineering effect.
Table 18 Stability (KN) of asphalt mixture cores.
Mixture type Proposed modified asphalt mixture core 5%SBS modified asphalt mixture core
Stability 11.12 9.02 10.22 11.88 8.67 12.00 9.21 9.44 13.23 13.44 12.23 12.39 12.94 14.18 12.99 13.24
Average value 10.20 13.08

sections.heading: 8. Conclusions
sections.text:
A composite modified technique using nano-materials (SiO2) and polymers (SBR and PE) was studied to improve the comprehensive performance of nano-modified asphalt binder. With the help of orthogonal test and analysis method, the influence trends of different types of nano-materials and polymers on pavement performance of modified asphalt binder were analyzed, and the optimal modified asphalt formulas was determined: 0.5% SiO2 + 5%SBR + 1%PE.
Compared to two typical types of asphalt binder including 5% SBS modified asphalt binder and AH-70 base asphalt binder, the high-temperature performance, low-temperature performance and aging resistance of the proposed modified asphalt binder have a significant improvement. When the proposed modified asphalt binder is used in asphalt mixture, its pavement performance is also superior to 5%SBS modified asphalt binder and AH-70 base asphalt binder. Furthermore, the proposed modified asphalt binder has been used in practical engineering named the 1st section of ‘‘Dong-Yu” highway in Shanxi province of China, which obtains a satisfactory engineering effect.

sections.text: This study is sponsored by Shanghai PPD Technologies, Ltd., and in part by the National Natural Science Foundation of China under grants U1134206, and by Jiangsu Natural Science Foundation under Grant SBK200910046, to which the authors are very grateful.

With the development of research work and the application of various new binder materials, especially when the polymer modified asphalt binders are used, G⁄/sind is suggested to be ineffective in capturing the contribution to rutting resistance [1].

metadata.abstractText: Nano-materials have a great potent ial as modifiers for enhancing performance of base asphalt binder. However, existing studies in the literature focus on the improvement of high-temperature performance of base asphalt binder, whereas the low-temperature performance of base asphalt binder is overlooked. Studies have shown that nano-materials will even weaken the low-temperature performance of base asphalt binder. To address this issue, nano-materials and polymers as composite modifiers are studied to improve base asphalt performance at both high temperature and low temperature. Nano-materials and polymers were screened and selected according to conventional performance indicator of asphalt binder, including softening point, ductility at 5 C and viscosity at 60 C. Optimal formulas of composite modifiers were determined using orthogonal experiment design and range analysis. SHRP tests including RTFOT, DSR and BBR tests were conducted to better evaluate the anti-aging, high-temperature performance and low temperature performance (i.e., crack resistance and water stability) of the proposed optimal composite modified asphalt binder against performances of 5%SBS modified asphalt binder and AH-70 base asphalt binder, showing an improved pavement performance. 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
